title: Will Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu meet to discuss the peace process before 1 June 2017?
preds:
Jason Greenblatt, Pres. Trump's longtime lawyer who is now leading efforts to "bring a lasting peace to Israel," met with Abbas in the West Bank last week, a day after Greenblatt met with Netanyahu to discuss Israeli settlements.  
http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/14/520099578/trumps-point-man-on-israel-visits-netanyahu-and-abbas Trump is meeting with Netanyahu in Israel this week. Although Abbas said he was ready to meet with Israel's PM, there are no news indicating they are close to setting up a date.
There is no appetite for this.
I see nothing to indicate there will be any serious talks any time soon.

The Palestinians in Israel are a group of Arab Muslims, with some Christians, quarantined to a few chunks of land within a Jewish state.  The US needs Israel as a strong ally in the middle east regardless of human rights violations which occur regularly.  Also, the US has 5 of the top 10 Jewish populated cities in the world and the majority of Jews are Zionists.  The Zionist lobby is very strong in Washington.  President Trump has tasked Jared Kushner with solving the problem.  Unless Israel grows new land or Egypt is willing to change its borders, the Palestinians and Jews in Israel will stay in a constant state of unrest that causes regular violence.  In my opinion, rather than assigning anyone with the task of solving the problem, we leave Israel alone and occasionally scold them when their human rights abuses become too egregious.  I know my point of view is isolationist and cold, but the US is comfortable with these type allies.  The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is officially Wahabi Muslim and is first in persons beheaded in a UN recognized country.

https://www.breakingisraelnews.com/87921/arab-media-abbas-netanyahu-trump-plan-three-way-summit/#sQiOTIsxZJp1x2XF.97 The question doesn’t specify that it has to be a bilateral meeting, so I think that if there’s a trilateral meeting (Trump, Abbas & Netanyahu) it would satisfy. However, now it is looking that what will happen May 23rd is not a trilateral meeting, but an announcement of one to be held on some other date. (http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/PA-President-Abbas-reportedly-ready-for-Netanyahu-Trump-meeting-490386) Therefore, I'm reducing my forecast.

thanks @Anneinak! I raised m forecast. It's still fairly low though, since the timeframe is very short and the motivation for netanyahu to participate in such a meeting is very unclear for me. What does he have to gain? And what could possibly be a result (or even the agenda) of such a fairly spontaneous meeting?
On the other hand: Trump needs a win, and even a picture of Netanyahu and Abbas in the same room would count as one. And Netanyahu might choose not to disappoint Trump. Meeting on foreign minister-level seems more probable to me right now.

This question doesn't specify that it has to be a bilateral meeting, so I think that if there's a trilateral meeting May 23rd between Trump, Abbas & Netanyahu, it would resolve as yes.  So far, there's been no word about Netanyahu being willing to meet, however.

"Trump is expected to issue invitations to a trilateral summit when he visits Jerusalem and Bethlehem later this month, according to television station i24."
http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/PA-President-Abbas-reportedly-ready-for-Netanyahu-Trump-meeting-490386

Leading Hamas official says no softened stance toward Israel Mughrabi (2017) Wed May 10, states that: One of Hamas's most senior officials said on Wednesday a document published by the Islamist Palestinian group last week was not a substitute for its founding charter, which advocates Israel's destruction. Speaking in Gaza City, Mahmoud al-Zahar, a regular critic of Israel, said the political policy document announced in Qatar on May 1 by Hamas's outgoing chief Khaled Meshaal did not contradict its founding covenant, published in 1988. Trailed for weeks by Hamas officials, the document appeared to be an attempt to soften the group's language toward Israel. But it still called for "the liberation of all of historical Palestine", said armed resistance was a means to achieve that goal, and did not recognize Israel's right to exist. "The pledge Hamas made before God was to liberate all of Palestine," Zahar said on Wednesday. "The charter is the core of (Hamas's) position and the mechanism of this position is the document." Many Western countries classify Hamas as a terrorist group over its failure to renounce violence, recognize Israel's right to exist, and accept existing interim Israeli-Palestinian peace agreements. In its new document, Hamas said it agrees to a transitional Palestinian state within frontiers pre-dating the 1967 Middle East war but continues to oppose recognizing Israel's right to exist and backs an armed struggle. Western-backed Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who heads the rival Fatah movement that controls the Israeli-occupied West Bank, recognizes Israel and seeks a final peace agreement based on those lines. U.S. President Donald Trump will meet Abbas and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu when he visits the region later this month, and a summit to restart peace talks stalled since 2014 has been mentioned in media reports (para. 1-7). Mughrabi, N. (2017). Leading Hamas official says no softened stance toward Israel. Reuters. Middle East and Northern Africa. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-palestinians-hamas-idUSKBN1862PK

Since Abbas visited Trump at the White House he's said he'd be willing to meet with Netanyahu & Trump.  There's some speculation that this might occur in late May when Trump goes to Israel.  I've not read any statements from Netanyahu, however.

Netanyahu tosses Hamas policy paper on Israel into waste bin Lewis (2017) Sun May 7, states that: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday symbolically tossed into a bin a Hamas policy paper published last week that set out an apparent softening of the Palestinian Islamist group's stance toward Israel. In a document issued last Monday, Hamas said it was dropping its longstanding call for Israel's destruction, but said it still rejected the Jewish state's right to exist and continued to back "armed struggle" against it. The Israeli government has said the document aimed to deceive the world that Hamas was becoming more moderate (para. 1-3). Lewis, O. (2017). Netanyahu tosses Hamas policy paper on Israel into waste bin. Reuters. Middle East and North Africa. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-palestinians-hamas-netanyahu-idUSKBN1830YX
It seems like everyone wants to be the hero/peacemaker all of a sudden:  Putin, Trump & al-Sisi.
Unless there is a successful and well respected outside broker, neither Abbas nor Netanyahu camp side has a clear incentive. Each will play hardline.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-palestinian-idUSKBN17Z06S
The lads may put on a little pantomime by way of a sop for M. Petits-Doigts, who as a total amateur is easily fooled, but probably not before this Q expires.  Whenever the meet happens, if it does, the Prez he will proclaim a great success and leave the details to his slightly less gormless son-in-law.  Nothing will come of it.  He will blame Obama or the media for this.  Moving up from 0 to 1, just in case; most likely move back down in a couple of days, though.
Revised incorrect estimate.  Netanyahu will not meet with Abbas, discussions between Trump and Abbas presumably will include discussions about a future ME Summit ...
Abbas is visiting the White House on May 3 for talks to "revive the Mideast peace process" but that doesn't seem to allow enough time for a meeting with Netanyahu to happen by the beginning of June.
Guess I'll go from one to zero.
War enthusiasts with RPGs are in Syria and norther Iraq. So long as they are not firing at Israel, that is peace.
Unlikely, with Bibi thinking he's got a friend in Trump.
not the peace process but security

Point-blank killing of senior Hamas operative deepens tensions between Israel, Gaza Eglash and Balousha (2017) March 26, states that: JERUSALEM — Hamas closed its only civilian border crossing with Israel on Sunday, and Israeli troops were on high alert as tensions between the two enemies continued to rise two days after a senior Hamas operative was mysteriously shot at point-blank range in the garage of his home. Hamas has accused Israel of being behind the killing of Mazen Fuqaha, 38, a senior commander in the militant Islamist movement’s military wing. He spent nine years in an Israeli prison for his part in planning suicide bombings that killed dozens of Israeli civilians during the second intifada, or uprising, in the early 2000s.  Fuqaha was one of more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners released in 2011 in exchange for Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit. Upon his release, Fuqaha was barred from returning to his childhood village in the West Bank and expelled to the Gaza Strip. From there, he managed Hamas’s military operations in the West Bank.  His death has brought tensions between Israel and Hamas to their highest level since 2014, when the two sides fought a 50-day war that killed about 74 Israelis and more than 2,100 Palestinians. This is the first-time Hamas has closed the Erez crossing, a checkpoint most frequently used by Gazans seeking health care in Israel and the West Bank. Erez is also used by aid workers and foreign journalists seeking to enter Gaza. Gaza also has a crossing into Egypt, but that is almost permanently closed. Hamas, which Israel and the United States consider a terrorist organization, set up checkpoints across Gaza in pursuit of those who might have been involved in Fuqaha’s killing. “We say it clearly that the crime was planned and conducted by the Zionist enemy. And the enemy will be responsible for the crime consequences,” Hamas’s military wing, the Izzedine al-Qassam Brigades, said in a statement (para.1-7). Eglash, R. & Balousha, H. (2017). Point-blank killing of senior Hamas operative deepens tensions between Israel, Gaza. The Washington Post. Middle East. Retrieved from
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/assassination-of-senior-hamas-operative-sparks-tensions-between-israel-gaza/2017/03/26/b0d7a056-1221-11e7-924b-58851f3a675d_story.html
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Israel ignores U.N. demand for end to settlement building: U.N. Nichols (2017) March 24, states that: Israel has ignored a demand by the United Nations Security Council to halt settlement building and some Palestinian groups are continuing to incite violence against Jews, U.N. Middle East envoy Nickolay Mladenov told the 15-member body on Friday. It was Mladenov's first report on the implementation a Dec. 23 resolution adopted by the council with 14 votes in favor and a U.S. abstention. Then President-elect Donald Trump and Israel had urged Washington to wield its veto. "The resolution calls on Israel to take steps 'to cease all settlements activities in the occupied Palestinian territory including east Jerusalem.' No such steps have been taken during the reporting period," Mladenov told the council. Israel for decades has pursued a policy of constructing Jewish settlements on territory captured by Israel in a 1967 war with its Arab neighbors. Most countries view Israeli settlement activity as illegal and an obstacle to peace. Israel disagrees. The Palestinians want an independent state in the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem. "Many of the advancements that were made in the past three months will further sever the territorial contiguity of a future Palestinian state and accelerate the fragmentation of the West Bank," said Mladenov of settlements, adding that they were "one of the main obstacles to peace." Mladenov also said an increase in rockets fired from Gaza toward Israel was a "worrying development" and described it as regrettable that Palestinian Authority officials had not condemned attacks against Israelis. "The continued incitement to violence against Jews emanating from Hamas extremists and some Palestinian groups is unacceptable and undermines trust and the prospects for peace," he said. "Reactions by Hamas officials to terror attacks against Israelis have been particularly reprehensible and deserve condemnation," Mladenov said. The United States traditionally shields Israel, Washington's long-time ally that receives more than $3 billion in annual U.S. military aid, from council action. The five council veto powers are the United States, Russia, France, Britain and China. The resolution, put forward by New Zealand, Malaysia, Venezuela and Senegal a day after Egypt withdrew it under pressure from Israel and Trump, was the first adopted by the council on Israel and the Palestinians in nearly eight years (para. 1-11). Nichols, M. (2017). Israel ignores U.N. demand for end to settlement building: U.N. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-palestinians-un-idUSKBN16V2ME

Hezbollah says U.N. 'weak' after critical Israel report pulled Francis and Mughrabi (2017) Sat Mar 18, states that: The leader of the Lebanese Hezbollah movement denounced the United Nations on Saturday as weak after the withdrawal of a report accusing Israel of imposing an "apartheid regime" on Palestinians. A senior U.N. official resigned on Friday after the secretary-general asked her to remove the report, published by the United Nation's Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia (ESCWA), from the internet. U.N. Under-Secretary General and ESCWA Executive Secretary Rima Khalaf said she was leaving after "powerful member states" had pressured the world body and its chief with "vicious attacks and threats". Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said in a televised speech on Saturday that the incident served as a reminder of the "truth of this organization, that it's weak ... and it succumbs to the will of the United States and Israel". The U.N. is "incapable of taking a stand" and the debacle over the report proved it cannot be counted on "to defend human rights in our region," he said. Hanan Ashrawi, a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization's executive committee, also criticized the decision and called on the report to be reinstated.
ESCWA, which comprises 18 Arab states, published the report on Wednesday and said it was the first time a U.N. body had clearly charged that Israel "has established an apartheid regime that dominates the Palestinian people as a whole" (para. 1-7). Francis, E. & Mughrabi, N. (2017). Hezbollah says U.N. 'weak' after critical Israel report pulled. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-un-israel-report-hezbollah-idUSKBN16P0LA

Ministers from more than 70 countries meet in Paris on Sunday as part of a French plan to restore momentum to the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. There have been no talks between the two sides since an American-brokered effort fizzled out in 2014. Many observers now think hopes for the “two-state solution”, which would see the mutual recognition of Israel and Palestine within agreed borders and Jerusalem as a shared capital, are all but dead. Israel has refused to attend (though the president of the Palestinian Authority will be there), arguing that only direct talks, not multilateral ones, can solve the issue. Participants will reaffirm their own commitment to the two-state solution, will call on the Israeli and Palestinian governments to disassociate themselves from those (including members of Israel’s ruling coalition) who reject it, and will dangle some economic and political incentives to encourage progress. But this thin gruel is unlikely to satisfy anyone

Khalidi (2016) Saturday 31 December, states that: As 2017 dawns, the ghost of Lord Balfour still haunts us. Just as the British foreign secretary’s 1917 declaration considered only how the Zionist movement could serve the interests of the greatest power of its day, so has the recent speech of the US secretary of state, John Kerry, advocating a two-state solution addressed mainly the interests of today’s superpower and its protégé, Israel. There has been some progress since 1917: there is no mention whatsoever of Palestinians or Arabs in the Balfour Declaration, whereas Kerry paid ample lip service to the Palestinians, albeit always in relation to Israel’s concerns and desires.
Lost in the uproar caused in some circles by the condemnation of Israeli settlements embodied in Kerry’s speech and in UN security council resolution 2334 is the fact that, in line with previous US policies on Palestine, both ignore basic rights of the Palestinian people, and the requirements of international law, of justice and of equity.
However, this is not just about Israel’s metastasizing colonial settlement project, important though that is. Much as they may have enraged Israel’s government and its American enablers, the Obama/Kerry parameters and UNSC 2334 are simply inadequate as the basis for a lasting solution. This problem did not start in 1967, and it will not disappear simply by resolving the settlement issue, which in any case neither parameters nor resolution will do (para. 1-2). Khalidi, R. (2016). John Kerry's two-state plan still falls short in solving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The Guardian. Middle East Peace talks. Opinion. Retrieved from
https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/dec/31/israel-palestine-two-state-solution-flaws-john-kerry-plan

Highly unlikely. The recent UNSC resolution has further isolated Israel and made a peace process much more difficult to initiate. The Abbas-Netanyahu relationship is in deadlock with Abbas refusing direct negotiations before Israel meets certain preconditions including a settlement freeze and release of prisoners, and Netanyahu avoiding participation in multilateral conferences, most recently refusing to attend a proposed conference in Paris. 
The wild card here is Trump. It is quite likely that Trump will be a forceful backer of Netanyahu's right wing coalition, which would make the Palestinians more reluctant to engage in direct negotiations. If Trump moves the US Embassy to Jerusalem, its ability to host peace talks is eliminated, at least in the short term.  Note: I think covert talks are more likely than 5%, but given that there is no way to identify whether such talks have occurred I assume the question means publicly acknowledged negotiations.

The passage of the current bill in the Knesset has further solidified the near improbability of talks between the parties. Let a* be an element of A (the set of possible paths to talks for Israelis; a* should be regarded as the best maximized policy choice for Israelis ).   b* is a member of B (for Palestinians, where b* is the maximized policy preference for Palestinian representatives), then the distance between (a*, b*) in the probability space is the absolute difference between the parties.  An ideal point is a member of t* (actual agreement toward talks); S* = I a* - b* I where a*. b* is in the set of R (real numbers); in this case  (0 > S* < 1).   Reformulating this outcome with constraints. it is possible to determine the probability of Pr ( t*)  (a member of T) ). The distance from t* is the policy distance for both Palestinians and Israeli's.  As long as the distance( S* <  t*) , there remains little probability of any peace talks. The closer each party is to each other's ideal point (a*, b*), then the likelihood of talks become greater, is S* = I a* - b* I where S meets the condition (S* = I a* -= b* I), where each (a* is a member of A, b* is a member of B) independent from each other, has a single peaked preference, and is able to obtain a unique Nash Equilibrium, then a solution has been found, otherwise, none (  T < S* ) for all A, B and T. Typical constraints are large set which includes, acts of terror,  West Bank violence, reactions from the international community, the credibility of Israel's threats, and its ability to maintain security, domestic stability, and increased territorial distance between Israel and its regional enemies.  Additional constraints are implied.

It depends, I think, whether Trump ends up in the White House or in an asylum, where he belongs in my opinion.
Both the Palestinians and Israelis have a common problem, and that is the stability in the region.
They could fight their feud, with all human suffering involved, without an all to serious destabilizing of the Middle East.
At this moment they have cope with the fact, that most countries in their neighbourhood were once relatively stable gouvernments, now they are in turmoil and nobody has a clue about the outcome.
In Russia is an institutionalysed mob in control, in the US you have a psychriatic case after this presidential election. Which more or less makes the world around the Palestinian Israëli conflict. You simply cannot fight in peace, when everybody and everyting around you is trying to suck you in an abyss, which could lead to total annilation of both conflictpartners. I think both Israel and the Palestines do realize this and, I tink they start to realize that they have to work grudginly together to survive in the Middle East turmoil.

With Friedman as ambassador to Israel?  Funny.
A meeting while not likely is not impossible if for no other reason than for both sides to keep up the appearance of a peace process. Real progress toward peace is extremely unlikely.

The question is not whether there will be any meaningful progress (they will not), but just whether they will meet.  Not impossible given international pressure to be seen to be doing something, but still highly unlikely.

The series of purported antagonisms from both sides, along with Trump's intention to move the American embassy to Jerusalem, and the solidification of geographical space within Israel for settlements  (are bound to further antagonize Palestinians) with resulting consequence of, potentially, a continuation of the series of Intifada's will undoubtedly destabilize the relationship between the Israeli's and West Bank Palestinians and result in decreasing trust regarding motivations, intentions, and acts on both sides.   It is highly likely that we will not see any peace discussions among these parties.  Israel's position is direct, multilateral talks for resolution of the conflict, and the Palestinians require that settlement construction and expansion be stopped.  Consequently a difficult stalemate.

Netanyahu has no interest in peace and Trump's public statements suggest he isn't either. However, I see a very small possibility that Netanyahu will feel he has all the advantages and so now is the time to negotiate.

The French are aware that it is currently impossible to get Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate in earnest, let alone reach a peace agreement, officials in Paris said. The proposed international conference is not intended to force either side into concessions or even to formulate a framework for a future agreement.

Donald Trump will influence the situation in the ME towards a direction in which Israel can increasingly demand what they want from the Palestinians. Abbas on the other hand has made clear that he demands among other things a settlement freeze in order to enter negotiations. They will almost surely not enter negotiations, unless something happens which dramatically forces the hand of the Palestinians.
